This problem studies the case of a drunk postman who has to deliver $n$ letter and $n$ boxes but assigns each letter randomly.

### Question 1: Right permutation

What is the probability that each letter goes to the right box ?

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"}
## ðŸ’¡ Solution
Since $Card(\mathcal{S}_n) = n!$, we have $\boxed{\mathbb{P}( \sigma=id)=\frac{1}{n!}}$
:::

### Question 2: At least one letter right

What is the probability that at least one letter goes to the right box ?

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"}
## ðŸ’¡ Hint
Define the event $A_i$ : "The letter i goes to the box i" and use the Poincare formula for the probability of the union.
:::

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"}
## ðŸ’¡ Solution

Define the event $A_i$ : "The letter i goes to the box i, since a good permutation let's i unchanged and randomly permutes the others, we get $\mathbb{P}(A_i) = \frac{(n-1)!}{n!} = \frac{1}{n}$

By the Poincare formula, we find  
$\mathbb{P}(\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i) = \sum_{k=1}^n (-1)^{k-1} \sum_{1\le i_1 < ... < i_k  \le n} \mathbb{P}(A_{i_1} \cap ... \cap A_{i_k})=\sum_{k=1}^n (-1)^{k-1}\binom{n}{k}\frac{(n-k)!}{n!} = \sum_{k=1}^n \frac{(-1)^{k-1}}{k!}.$

Accordingly, we have
$$\boxed{\mathbb{P}(\text{at least one good letter})=1-\sum_{k=0}^n \frac{(-1)^{k}}{k!} \rightarrow_{n\to\infty} 1-e^{-1}\approx0.632.}$$
:::

### Question 3: No right letter

What is the probability that no letters are delivered to the right box ?

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"}
## ðŸ’¡ Solution

We have $$\boxed{\mathbb{P}(\text{no good letter})= 1-\mathbb{P}(\text{at least one good letter})=e^{-1} \approx 0.368.}$$

We can find the number of ways that no letter are right delivered: probability one permutation leeds to no good letter * number of permutations : $d_n = n!e^{-1}.$
:::
